intro: Purshia subintegra, commonly known as the Townsend's poppy, is a flowering plant native to the western United States and parts of Canada. It is a member of the Papaveraceae family, which includes罂粟 (poppies) and other related species. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky habitats and is characterized by its showy, bright yellow to orange flowers. Its leaves are palmately lobed and often have a fuzzy texture, while its stems are usually hairy. The plant produces capsule fruits that contain numerous small, elliptical seeds.
